title-group.article-title: Prediction of failure envelopes and stress–strain curves of fiber composite laminates under triaxial loads

article-meta.aff: 2School of Naval Architecture, Ocean and Civil Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, China

author-notes.corresp: Jianqiao Ye, Department of Engineering, Lancaster University, Lancaster, LA1 4YR, UK Email: j.ye2@lancaster.ac.uk

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Evaluation of Theories for Predicting Failure in Polymer Composite Laminates Under 3-D States of Stress: Part A of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II)

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This article presents a methodology for predicting the stress–strain response and failure behavior of fiber composite laminates. First, a stress transfer method is proposed by using the concept of the state space equation. The generalized plane strain deformation is assumed in the model. The state space equation was derived by using Fourier series expansions in the width direction and the layer refinement technique through the thickness. Secondly, Christensen’s stress-based failure criteria are adopted to predict failure of individual plies. Finally, the applications of the methodology are shown by predicting the failure envelopes and stress–strain curves of the test cases provided by the organizers of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Failure of composite laminates may be caused by transverse cracking, inter-laminar delamination and fiber breaks, or by a combination of these factors. Since there are many possible damage modes and the damage mechanism are very complex, no universal failure criterion can predict all possible modes of failure. A variety of failure criteria exist for failure analysis of laminated composites, e.g. maximum stress, maximum strain, interactive, micro-mechanics, damage mechanics, empirical, and probabilistic methods. From the literature survey in Soni,1 more than 90% of the designers used either maximum stress or maximum strain or quadratic polynomial criteria.2–5 A recent World Wide Failure Exercise on failure criteria of fiber-reinforced polymer composites has carried out a systematic research and a comprehensive review on the new development in the subject area.6

To carry out a failure analysis, an accurate stress analysis is a prerequisite. Numerous investigators have used various methods to calculate stress distributions in composite laminates. These include analytical, numerical, and semi-analytical methods. For the analytical approaches, previous analyses were mainly based on either the theory developed initially for isotropic materials or the classic laminate theory (CLT). Unfortunately, they yielded only average through-thickness values for the in-plane stresses and give no or unsatisfactory information about the important inter-laminar tractions.7 Some refined or higher order theories have been developed to overcome these shortfalls, but none seems to be widely accepted.

Numerical methods such as finite element method (FEM) and finite difference method (FDM) have also been used.8,9 Although FEM is probably one of the most universal methods that can be applied to problems involving any cross section and lamination profile, it is sometimes very computational expensive and even unreliable for interlaminar stress analysis of multi-layered laminates. In addition, it is very difficult and computational expensive for a FEM to meet the continuity requirement of both tractions and displacements between interlaminar layers.

Consequently some semi-analytical solutions were proposed combining a certain analytical technique with FEM or a layerwise laminate theory.10–14 The state space method is one of the semi-analytical methods that have been used to solve a large class of problems including laminated plates. The term ‘state space’ is often used in connection with linear control system where the principal concern is the relationship between inputs and outputs. For a laminate, the input and output are the respective tractions and displacements at the two lateral surfaces, while the interlaminar tractions are traced as ‘history’ of the system.

On the basis of an early version of the state space solution,15 Zhang et al.16 developed a new state space method to analyze three-dimensional interlaminar stresses in both cross-ply and angle-ply laminates subjected to in-plane loads. The new model is used in this article to compute deformations caused by in-plane loads, while the deformation due to the through-thickness loads is dealt with by a separate state space formulation. Because only linear deformations are considered, the principle of superposition is used to determine the stresses under triaxial loads. Thermal stresses are considered in the analysis by introducing thermal strains in the stress–strain constitutive law. The stresses under in-plane and through-thickness loads are computed separately, the sum of which yields the stresses due to the triaxial loads.

Due to the complexities and irregularities of composite materials, there is a lack of faith in failure predictions of the state of the art. Following the successful First World Wide Failure Exercise,6 the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II) aims at benchmarking and validating the current failure theories used for predicting the mechanical behavior of fiber-reinforced plastic composites under triaxial loadings. The exercise contains 12 well-defined test cases that take into account the effect of both in-plane and through thickness loads on failure predictions of laminated composites.17 Numerical prediction of failure of these test cases requires a flexible theoretical model that can handle triaxial loads and provide accurate through thickness stresses. The state space method is a three-dimensional stress analysis model, which has been used successfully to evaluate stress concentrations near free edges and transverse cracks15,16,18 and predict material property degradation due to transverse cracking.19,20 With some extension and modification, this is the first time that this model is applied to predict failure of composite laminates under triaxial loads. The failure theory used in this work is Christensen criterion21,22 that has been regarded as one of the most appropriate criteria for fiber composite materials. The combination of the state space stress solution and Christensen’s failure theory yields the failure envelopes and stress–strain relationships of the 10 test cases specified in WWFE-II. The numerical results are presented in the paper for future comparisons with physical tests.

sec.title: Stress analysis using the state space method
Fundamental equations
sec.p:
Consider an off-axis lamina (Figure 1) with principal directions (1-2-3) in the global x-y-z coordinate system. The lamina has constant thickness h, width L and infinite length. The displacements in the x, y and z directions are denoted by u, v and w, respectively. The lamina is made of a homogeneous, monoclinic and linearly elastic material whose principal directions, i.e. fiber directions 1 and 2, have an angle of θ to the x and y axes, respectively. Equations (1) to (3) below show the fundamental equations of such a lamina, where displacements, stresses and strains are defined in the usual way. Figure 1.
Nomenclature of an off-axis lamina.

sec.title: (a) Stress–strain relations
sec.p: The basic constitutive equation,23 for a linearly elastic monoclinic material is (1){∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z=0∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z=0∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z=0 . where Cij ' are stiffness coefficients that can be expressed by Young’s moduli, Poisson’s ratios, shear moduli and fiber orientation θ (see Appendix 2); αx, αy, αz and αxy are the respective coefficients of thermal expansion; and ΔT denotes a change of temperature. αxy=0 is used in this article.

sec.title: (c) Strain–displacement relations
sec.p: Suppose that the lamina is subjected to a uniform tension in the y direction, i.e. in the length direction. As the laminate is long, it has a constant longitudinal strain ε0. This constant strain is related to one of the applied in-plane stresses in the WWFE-II test cases. It follows that (4)ɛyy=∂v∂y=ɛ0.

This represents a generalized plane strain deformation,24,25 for which all components of stress and strain do not depend upon y. Consequently, the in-plane shear strain, ɛxy=(∂v)/(∂x), can be obtained, denoting distortion of a cross-sectional plane for anisotropic materials, or angle of rotation of such a plane for monoclinic materials.
To facilitate the following deduction process, let (5){∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z=0∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z=0∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z=0 .
From the third equation of equations (1) and (3), the following relation is obtained (6)∂w∂z=C1αu+C6αv+C7σzz+C5ɛ0.

By substituting equation (6) into the first, second and sixth equations of equation (1), the in-plane stresses can be expressed as (7){∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z=0∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z=0∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z=0 .

Inserting equation (7) into equation (2) and considering equation (6) as well as the fourth and fifth equations of equation (1), the following first-order partial differential equation can be obtained (8){∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z=0∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z=0∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z=0 .

Equation (8) is also called state space equation that relates displacements and through-thickness stresses to their gradient in the thickness direction. The solution of the first order differential equations will ultimately yield displacements and stresses as functions of the coordinate in the thickness direction. This solution is particularly suitable for predicting failure of laminates under the triaxial loads set by the WWFE-II.

sec.title: Displacements and stresses of a lamina
(a) Under in-plane loads
sec.p: When the lamina is under in-plane loads, the displacements u, v, and w can be expressed as (9){u(x,y,z)=u¯(x,z)+U(0)(z)(1-2xL)v(x,y,z)=v¯(x,z)+V(0)(z)(1-2xL)+ɛ0yw(x,y,z)=w(x,z) , where U(0)(z) and V(0)(z) are unknown boundary displacements that can be determined by imposing boundary conditions along the four edges. In equation (9), the following Fourier series expansions are assumed (10){u¯v¯wσxzσyzσzz}=∑m=0 ∞{U¯m(z)sin(ξx)V¯m(z)sin(ξx)Wm(z)cos(ξx)Xm(z)sin(ξx)Ym(z)sin(ξx)Zm(z)cos(ξx)}, where ξ=mπ/L; U¯m(z), V¯m(z), Wm(z), Xm(z), Ym(z) and Zm(z) are unknown z-dependent components of u¯, v¯, w, σxz, σyz, and σzz, respectively. At the two edges, x = 0 and L, u¯ and v¯ are both zero, while u and v exist due to the introduction of the two unknown functions, U(0)(z) and V(0)(z). Thus, the displacement field can satisfy any displacement conditions that are imposed on the four side surfaces of Figure 1. In the case of a uniform extension, the axial displacement u is zero at x = L/2 and the integer m in Equation (10) takes only even numbers, i.e. m = 0, 2, 4, … .

By introducing equations (9) and (10) into (8), the following non-homogenous state space equation for an arbitrary value of m is obtained (11a)ddz{Fm(z)}=[Gm]{Fm(z)}+{Bm(z)}, where (11b){Fm(z)}=[U¯m(z)V¯m(z)Wm(z)Xm(z)Ym(z)Zm(z)]T, (11c)[Gm]=[00ξ-C12C110000C11-C130C1ξC6ξ000C7C2ξ2C9ξ2000-C1ξC9ξ2C14ξ2000-C6ξ000-ξ00], (11d){∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z=0∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z=0∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z=0 . (11e){Bm(z)}=[-2mπ(1+cosmπ)dU (0)(z)dz,-2mπ(1+cosmπ)dV (0)(z)dz,0,0,0,0]T (m=2,4,6…).

sec.title: (b) Under through-thickness loads
sec.p: In the case of normal pressure applied on the top and bottom surfaces, the state vectors are expanded as (12){uvwσxzσyzσzz}=∑m=0 ∞{Um(z)cos(ξx)Vm(z)cos(ξx)Wm(z)sin(ξx)Xm(z)cos(ξx)Ym(z)cos(ξx)Zm(z)sin(ξx)},
Because the axial displacement u is zero at x = L/2, the integer m in equation (12) takes only odd numbers, i.e. m = 1, 3, 5, … .

Substituting equations (9) and (12) into (8) and expanding 1 into Fourier series as 1=2π∑m=1 ∞1-cosmπmsinmπxL, the following state space equation is derived. (13a)ddz{Fm(z)}=[Gm]{Fm(z)}+{Bm(z)}, where (13b)[Gm]=[00-ξC12C110000C11-C130-C1ξ-C6ξ000C7C2ξ2C9ξ2000C1ξC9ξ2C14ξ2000C6ξ000ξ00], (13c){Bm(z)}=[0,0,(C5ɛ0-CαΔT)2(1-cosmπ)mπ,0,0,0]T

sec.title: Solution of the state space equation
(a) A single lamina
sec.p: The solution of the non-homogenous state space equations (11) and (13) is (14){∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z=0∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z=0∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z=0 .

In particular, at z = h, (15){Fm(h)}=[Dm(h)]{Fm(0)}+{Hm(h)}, where [Dm(h)] is called transfer matrix. The calculation of the two constant matrices, [Dm(h)] and {Hm(h)}, in Equation (15) can be found from Ye.7

sec.title: (b) A multi-layer angle-ply laminate
sec.p: Consider a long multi-layered general angle-ply laminate with thickness H and width L. Again the laminate is subjected to a constant longitudinal strain ε0. We may imagine that it is composed of N fictitious sub-layers, each of which may have different thickness. However, it is assumed that the thickness of all the fictitious sub-layers approach zero uniformly as N approaches infinity. Assuming, in addition, that different sub-layers may be composed of different monoclinic materials, two types of material interfaces are distinguished in the material; the fictitious interfaces that separate sub-layers with the same material properties and the real ones that separate sub-layers composed of different materials. Equations (11) or (13) and (14) and (15) are considered adequate for the solutions of these sub-layers. The state space equation and the form of solution of an arbitrary sub-layer, e.g. the jth one whose thickness is hj, can be obtained easily by replacing h with hj in equations (11) or (13) and (14) and (15). The state space equation of the jth sub-layer then becomes (16)ddz{Fm(z)}j=[Gm]j{Fm(z)}j+{Bm(z)}j.

After repeating the above process for all individual sub-layers and with appropriate continuity requirements imposed at all the real and fictitious interfaces, a solution for the entire laminate can be formulated. In addition, the solution can be found to the required accuracy by increasing the total number of the thin layers.
The solution of equation (16) at z = hj is (17){Fm(hj)}j=[Dm(hj)]j{Fm(0)}j+{Hm(hj)}j.

By introducing the following continuity conditions at all interfaces, i.e. (18){Fm(0)}j+1={Fm(hj)}j, j=1,2,…,N-1, and using equations (17) and (18) recursively, a relationship between the state vectors on the top and bottom surfaces of the laminate is established as follows (19a){Fm(hN)}N=[D¯m]N{Fm(0)}1+{H¯m}, where (19b)[D¯m]N=( Πj=N 1[Dm(hj)]j), (19c){∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z=0∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z=0∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z=0 .
{Fm(hN)}N and {Fm(0)}1 are, respectively, the state vectors at the top and bottom surfaces of the laminate.

sec.title: Boundary conditions
sec.p: The stress and strain conditions at the edges of the laminate can be imposed by following the procedure described in Zhang et al.18–20 In general, after a laminate is divided into sub-layers, which has been done in the process of forming the state space equation, both strains and displacements can be introduced along the edges of each interface, by which the stresses on the four side surfaces are computed and compared with the applied tractions. Obviously, an accurate satisfaction of boundary conditions can be achieved by choosing a sufficient large number of sub-layers. The current model can deal with any combination of normal stresses, in-plane shear stresses and three-dimensional boundary displacements imposed on the four side surfaces. The only boundary traction that cannot be introduced into the analytical model of the present form is the shear stress in the thickness direction (τzy in Cases 10 and 11) due to the presumed series expansions of the shear stress that vanishes constantly on the side surfaces. It is worthwhile mentioning here that the limitation does not affect the accuracy of the calculation on the through thickness shear stresses within the materials caused by any other boundary traction. The inclusion of the through thickness shear on the boundary will be dealt with in the second phase of the exercise.
The boundary conditions at the side surfaces are satisfied as follows.

sec.title: (a) Under in-plane loads
sec.p: Upon using the traction free conditions at the top and bottom surfaces, i.e. σxz=σyz=σzz=0, the following stress conditions are obtained (20){[Xm(0)Ym(0)Zm(0)]1 T =[000]T[Xm(hN)Ym(hN)Zm(hN)]N T=[000]T .

Substituting equation (20) into equation (19) yields the following linear algebra equation system (21)[D¯41D¯42D¯43D¯51D¯52D¯53D¯61D¯62D¯63]{UmVmWm}1=-{H¯m4H¯m5H¯m6}, where D¯ij and H¯mi are the relevant elements in [D¯m] and {H¯m}, respectively. For the boundary conditions on the two surfaces at x = 0 and L (Figure 1), the shear stress σxz=0 is automatically satisfied as a result of the Fourier series expansions in equation (10), while the stresses σxx and σxy can take any prescribed values. σxy=0 is imposed in the calculation of this article.

sec.title: (b) Under through-thickness loads
sec.p: The boundary conditions of the top and bottom surfaces subjected to uniformly distributed pressure q are σxz=σyz=0 and σzz=-q, i.e. (22){[Xm(0)Ym(0)Zm(0)]1 T =[00-2q(1-cosmπ)mπ]T[Xm(hN)Ym(hN)Zm(hN)]N T =[00-2q(1-cosmπ)mπ]T . where the surface pressure has been expanded into Fourier series. By inserting equation (22) into equation (19), the following equation is obtained. (23){∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z=0∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z=0∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z=0 .
The boundary tractions can be any pre-defined values on the two side surfaces at x = 0 and L. In this study, they are all zeros, i.e. σxx=σxz=σxy=0.

Both equations (21) and (23) are sets of linear algebra equations in terms of the three displacement components on the top surface. The dimension of both equations is only three, completely independent of the number of the sub-layers used in the previous calculations. The three displacement components are obtained from both equations (21) and (23), and are then substituted into equation (17) to find the respective state vectors at all interfaces.
For a triaxial loading case, the superposition of the above solutions, i.e. the summation of the results predicted separately under the in-plane and through-thickness loads, is required.

It is worth mentioning that the current model includes stress concentration near the free edges, and, therefore, the geometrical parameters, L and H are chosen such that the edge effect, which is not of interest of this exercise, is minimum. In the calculation, L = 1000 mm and H = 0.25 mm are used to eliminate the edge effects on the stresses in the central region (x = L/2) of the laminates. The computed stresses are then introduced into the adopted failure criteria.

sec.title: Lamina failure criterion
sec.p: There are a large number of failure criteria for isotropic and fiber composite materials in the literature Among them, the theories proposed by Hashin,11 Tsai–Wu2 and Christensen23,24 stand out as having the capacity of dealing with failure of highly anisotropic composite materials and were motivated by the properties of carbon-polymer systems. Comparing with the other two criteria, Christensen’s failure criteria recognise difference in matrix-controlled and fiber-controlled failure modes and treat the two modes separately. The Tsai–Wu criteria does not decompose into separate fiber-and matrix-controlled modes, while the Hashin theory requires further decomposition of the two fundamental failure modes, which is not necessary and appropriate sometimes. Christensen criteria are stress based that are physically realistic and can be easily implemented in a three dimension stress analysis process. The criteria include forms for both isotropic matrix and anisotropic fiber materials. The form for anisotropic fiber composite materials requires six strength properties at lamina level that are from homogenization of a heterogeneous composite layer. Since the material properties used in the present stress analysis are based on homogenization of a lamina, this common feature also makes it feasible to predict failure of fiber composites by combining the present stress analysis and Christensen’s failure criteria. In the following failure analysis, Christensen’s latest developed failure criteria,26,27 are used. The failure criteria were developed for both isotropic materials and highly anisotropic materials such as carbon fiber/polymer matrix composites.

sec.title: Criterion for isotropic materials
sec.p: For an isotropic material, the criterion takes the historic assumption that failure will not occur if the material is under hydrostatic pressure. Apparently, this assumption leads to an open ended failure envelope. Failure will occur when a combination of the first invariant of the stress tensor, I1, and the second invariant of the deviatoric stress tensor, J2, exceeds a certain value that is uniquely related to the tensile and compressive strengths of the material. i.e. (24a)aI1+bJ2≤1

The two unknown parameters are determined by calibrating the criterion such that it specifies failure when the uniaxial stress reaches the values of failure in uniaxial tension and compression. The resulting failure criterion is as follows (24b){∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z=0∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z=0∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z=0 . where T¯ and C¯ are tensile and compressive strength of the material, respectively. The failure criterion is only valid for T¯ less than or equal to C¯, and does not apply or give any information when the uniaxial tensile strength is greater than compressive strength for a homogeneous and isotropic material. Apparently, if the tensile strength is greater than the compressive strength, criterion (24b) violates the universally recognized condition that isotropic materials would not fail under compressive hydrostatic stress. When the tensile and compressive strength are the same, the criterion is reduced to von Mises criterion.

When the tensile strength of a material is significantly smaller than its compressive strength, Christensen theory requires that an additional fracture criterion must also be satisfied to prevent brittle failure together with equation (24b). Thus, for (24c)T¯≤C¯2 (24d)σI≤T¯ where σI is the maximum tensile stress at a point and can be calculated as the maximum value of the three roots of the following cubic equation. (24e){∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z=0∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z=0∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z=0 .

sec.title: (b) Criteria for fiber reinforced composites
sec.p:
The failure criteria for fiber composite materials are defined by decomposing the failure modes into the matrix-controlled failure and the fiber-controlled failure. For both modes, Christensen’s criteria states again that failure will occur once a combination of a set of stress invariants exceeds a certain value. For the two failure modes, the sets of stress invariants are, respectively, related to the transverse (directions 2 and 3) and fiber (direction 1) directions. For a fiber composite with highly anisotropic stiffness, failure is controlled, respectively, by the transverse stress invariants and strength properties in the 2-3 plane for the matrix and the stress invariants and the strength properties in the fiber direction for the fiber. This assumption leads to an elliptic failure envelope in the 2-3 plane for the matrix failure, since the strain in the fiber direct is ignored due to the highly anisotropic stiffness. By calibrating both criteria to represent failures characterized by six lamina level strength properties, T¯11, C¯11, T¯22, C¯22, S¯23 and S¯12, which can all be measured by standard tests, one has:
Matrix-controlled failure
(25a){∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z=0∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z=0∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z=0 . where S¯23≥0.5T¯22C¯22 must be satisfied in order to have real roots from the criterion.
Fiber-controlled failure
(25b)-C¯11≤σ11≤T¯11 where, T¯11, C¯11, T¯22, C¯22 are the respective tensile and compressive strength in the fiber and transverse directions; S¯23 is the transverse shear strength and S¯12 are the longitudinal shear strength. All the material strengths appearing in equations (24) and (25) are values obtained from tests and are positive quantities.

sec.title: Predictions and discussion
sec.p: WWFE-II supplied the details of 12 test cases, in which the material properties, laminate lay-ups, loading configurations are all well defined. Contributors are required to predict failure envelopes or stress–strain curves of one epoxy matrix, six unidirectional laminae, two balanced angle-ply laminates, one quasi-isotropic laminate, and two orthotropic laminates. Details of the test cases and material properties can be found in Kaddour and Hinton.17 Nonlinear shear and transverse compressive stress–strain curves for the unidirectional laminae were also provided. However, in the present analysis, the stress–strain behavior of resin and a unidirectional lamina is assumed to be linearly elastic. Therefore, only the initial modulus is used to predict material failure. The effect of thermal stresses is included in test case 12. It is possible to include the nonlinearity in the failure analysis, subject to further development of the model.

The aforementioned state space method and failure criterion are applied to model the test cases in WWFE-II. Although the present model is capable of predicting through thickness stresses within a laminate, at the current stage, it cannot handle case 10 and 11, because the presumed stress field yields automatically zero boundary shear stress in the thickness direction. A state space finite element approach is being developed to remove all the restrictions on the current model. In this article, therefore, no predictions of test cases 10 and 11 are given. All the other test cases are calculated and their failure envelopes or stress–strain curves are shown in this section. It is worth mentioning that in this section the coordinate system is different to the one used in the section ‘Stress analysis using the state space method’, and is inconsistent with the coordinates defined in the instructions of WWFE-II where the x and y directions coincide with the y and x directions, respectively, of the theoretical model.

When a multi-layer laminate is loaded, an initial failure may take place first in a certain ply, but the laminate can still be capable of carrying more loads until a final catastrophic failure occurs. However, for most of the test cases in this exercise, e.g. in the cases of resin (test case 1) and unidirectional lamina lay-up (test cases 2, 3, and 5–7), the initial and the final failure loads had no distinction. Even for the multi-layer (+35°/−35°)s laminate (test case 8), the +35° and −35° layers share an equal risk of failure. Theoretically, the whole laminate fails when the first failure occurs. Thus, in this article, only the initial failure envelopes are predicted, though progressive failure can be taken into account in the model.

sec.title: Test case 1
sec.p:
In this test case, only the failure envelope of the resin, MY750 epoxy, is required to be predicted when it is subjected to triaxial loading (with σy = σz). The failure criteria for isotropic materials, equations (24), are used and the predicted failure envelope is shown in Figure 2. It can be seen that the envelope is a parabola in the normal stress space. The open-ended envelope is the result from the assumption that isotropic materials do not fail under compressive hydrostatic stress, which presents a safe loading path for isotropic materials. Figure 2.
Test case 1: Variation of the compressive strength (σx) of polymeric resin matrix (MY750 epoxy) with stress σy(=σz).

sec.title: Test cases 2, 3 and 4
sec.p:
Predictions of test cases 2, 3 and 4 for the unidirectional T300/PR319 lamina are presented in Figures 3, 4 and 5, respectively. In this group of test cases, the lamina is under equal triaxial normal stresses and in-plane shear stress. It can be seen from Figure 3 that the maximum shear stress that can be applied is 135.24 MPa when σ1 = σ2 = σ3 = −55 MPa. When σ1 = σ2 = σ3 = −135.21 or 24.16 MPa, the material will fail even there is no in-plane shear stress applied. It is worth saying that the peak shear stress, 135.2 MPa, is higher than the shear strength 97 MPa defined in the material properties. Figure 3 indicates that the presence of shear and normal stresses has coupling effects on the failure of a unidirectional lamina, though there are no extension-shear couplings in the constitutive equation. The couplings are introduced into the failure analysis by the failure criteria (equation (25a)). Figure 4 is obtained by converting the vertical axis in Figure 3 from shear stress to shear strain, i.e. dividing the vertical co-ordinates by the shear modulus, 1330 MPa. The current analytical model is based on the constitutive law of equation (1), where coupling between tension and shearing does not exist. Therefore, the shear stress–strain curve follows the Hooke’s law and is independent of the applied triaxial normal stresses. It is also worthwhile mentioning here that by the present failure analysis the material (case 3) fails under a hydrostatic pressure of 135.2 MPa, well below the required value of 600 MPa for the test case 4. Figure 3.
Test case 2: Variation of shear strength (τ12) with stress σ2(=σ1 = σ3) for a UD carbon/epoxy (T300/PR319). Figure 4.
Test case 3: Variation of failure shear strain (γ12) with stress σ2(=σ1 = σ3) for a UD carbon/epoxy (T300/PR319). Figure 5.
Test case 4: Shear stress–strain curve (τ12 versus γ12) for a UD carbon/epoxy (T300/PR319).

sec.title: Test cases 5, 6 and 7
sec.p:
Figures 6 to 8 present the stress failure envelopes of 0° E-glass/MY750, S-glass/epoxy, and A-S carbon/epoxy lamina under triaxial normal stresses, respectively. For test case 5, the matrix-controlled failure mode is used and an elliptical envelope is obtained in Figure 6. In comparison with the open-ended envelope shown in Figure 2 for the isotropic matrix material, the hydrostatic pressure apparently is not a safe loading path for the matrix failure mode of a fiber composite. For test cases 6 and 7, a combination of both matrix and fiber-controlled failure modes is observed and rectangular failure envelopes are predicted in Figures 7 and 8. The upper and lower limits are determined by the matrix-controlled failure criterion, and the left and right limits are obtained by the fiber-controlled failure equation. Figure 6.
Test case 5: Variation of transverse compressive strength σ2 with σ3 (where σ1 = σ3) for a UD Glass/epoxy (E-glass/MY750 epoxy). Figure 7.
Test case 6: Variation of the longitudinal strength σ1 with through-thickness stress (σ3 = σ2) for a UD glass/epoxy (S-glass/epoxy). Figure 8.
Test case 7: Variation of the longitudinal strength σ1 with through-thickness stress (σ3 = σ2) for a UD Carbon/epoxy (A-S carbon/epoxy).

In test case 6, the shear strength of epoxy, Sm = 52 MPa, is used instead of the through-thickness shear strength of S-glass/epoxy lamina, S23 = 40 MPa. This is because for the matrix-controlled failure (equation (25a)), S23≥0.5T22C22 must be satisfied to obtain real roots from equation (25a). It is reasonable to assume that the through-thickness shear strength of a lamina is approximately equal to the shear strength of its matrix.

Compared with the failure envelope of the isotropic matrix material in Figure 2, the failure envelopes of test cases 5, 6 and 7 are all closed. This shows that for a composite material failure occurs under hydrostatic pressure due to its anisotropy and change of failure modes.

sec.title: Test cases 8 and 9
sec.p:
Figures 9 and 10 show the stress failure envelops and stress–strain curves, respectively, of the (+35°/−35°)s E-glass/My750 laminate subjected to triaxial normal stresses (with σx = σz). The stress components in the global coordinates x-y-z are first evaluated by the stress analysis and then the stresses in the local coordinate 1-2-3 are determined by the stress transformation equations. The matrix-controlled failure criterion is used to predict the failure envelope of each ply. It can be seen from Figure 9 that, once again, an elliptical envelope is obtained. Figure 10 shows that the stress–strain curves (σy − εx, and σy − εy) of this loading process are linear and the axial stress increases until matrix failure occurs. Figure 9.
Test case 8: Variation of axial compressive strength σy with through-thickness stress σz for (+35/−35)s glass/epoxy laminate (E-glass/MY750 epoxy), where σx = σz. Figure 10.
Test case 9: Axial compressive stress strain curves for (+35/−35)s glass/epoxy laminate (E-glass/MY750 epoxy) under σx = σz = −100 MPa.

sec.title: Test cases 10 and 11
sec.p:
Due to the difficulty in applying through-thickness shear at the edges surfaces by using the current form of this model, the loading conditions provided in WWFE-II for test cases 10 and 11 are replaced by applying tri-axial direct stresses on the materials. The purpose of the modified tests is to assess the through-thickness strength of the materials. In the two tests, the failure envelope of the through-thickness stress σz and the in-plane stresses σx = σy are predicted. The failure envelope shown in Figure 11 is drawn from a combination of the matrix-controlled and fiber-controlled failure criteria. The identical failure envelope for the two test cases is the result of identical principal stresses in the ±45° and the 0°/90° layers. The vertical line on the left is associated with the compressive failure of the fiber and the other parts of the envelope are related to the matrix failure. Calculations also show that after failure of the matrix, the laminates can still carry in-plane tensile loads until fiber failure occurs at σx = σy = 1280 MPa. Figure 11.
Test cases 10 and 11: Variation of axial compressive and tensile strength σx with through-thickness stress σz for (0/90/+45/−45)s and (0/90)s carbon/epoxy laminates (IM7/8551-7), where σx = σy. (The loading conditions required in test cases 10 and 11 are replaced by tri-axial direct stresses due to the limitation of the form of the current model).

sec.title: Test case 12
sec.p:
In test case 12, the stress–strain curves (σz − εz, σz − εx and σz − εy) of the (0°/90°)s IM7/8551-7 laminate under through-thickness pressure are predicted and presented in Figure 12. In order to show the thermal effects on the compressive strength, a uniformly distributed temperature difference, ΔT = −157°C, is used to model the temperature drop from the stress free temperature, 177°C to the ambient temperature, 20°C. Due to the mismatch of the coefficients of thermal expansion in the two in-plane directions, a thermal residual stress of 23 MPa is produced. The initial strains at the room temperature are −0.42% and −0.003% in the through-thickness and the two in-plane directions, respectively. The matrix-controlled failure criterion is used to determine the maximum pressure. Again the stress increases linearly as the strain increases until the failure stress, −373.193 MPa, is reached. In comparison with the failure stress, −417.37 MPa, obtained without considering the thermal effect, a 10.58% reduction in compressive strength is observed, which indicates that the effect of the thermal residual stresses on the failure stress is very significant. Figure 12.
Test case 12: Compressive through-thickness stress–strain curves for (0/90)s carbon/epoxy laminate (IM7/8551-7).

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: A methodology, which consists of stress and failure analyses, has been presented for predicting the failure envelopes and macroscopic response of fiber composite laminates.

For the stress analysis, a semi-analytical method was proposed to evaluate three-dimensional stresses and displacements in general angle-ply laminates subjected to triaxial loads and uniform temperature changes. Due to the linear stress–strain behavior, the state of stress under triaxial loads was determined by superimposing the stresses due to in-plane loads to those obtained separately for through thickness loading. A generalized plane strain deformation was assumed in the in-plane load cases. The state space equation was derived by using Fourier series expansions in the width direction and the layer refinement technique through the thickness.

Comparing with other analytical solutions of laminated composites,28 the current model does not introduce any pre-assumptions on the through-thickness stress distribution, which enables the continuity of both displacements and stresses at the material interfaces be fully satisfied. This feature provides accurate predictions to the through-thickness stresses that are also vital in the future delamination analysis. Since the recursive formulation (equation (18)) is used to derive the state equations of the laminate, the dimension of the final state equation (equation (20) or (22)) does not depend on the number of layers of the laminate. Consequently, this method is particularly suitable to compute the stresses and carry out failure analysis of laminates with a large number of layers. This advantage makes it possible to use the state space method in practical design of multi-layered composites. A MATLAB computer code was written to carry out the stress analysis that requires input of lamina properties, laminate dimensions, lay-ups, and loading conditions. Output of the code includes three-dimensional displacement, stress and strain distributions of the laminates.

Christensen’s stress-based failure criteria were adopted to predict failure of individual ply. When an initial failure occurs in one or more plies, a multi-ply laminate may still have some load-carrying capacities. However, for all the predictions made in this article, the initial failure and the final failure occur simultaneously and they have overlapped failure envelopes. It was observed from all the test cases that coupling between the triaxial stresses has a strong effect on the failure modes of the laminates. The residual thermal stresses, shown in test case 12, reduced the failure strength significantly.

The present model is limited to linear analysis only. Further development of the model to include nonlinear analysis is needed. The model fails to analyze cases (10) and (11) specified by the organizers.17 This is due to the difficulties in applying the prescribed through-thickness shear stresses on the edge surfaces. However, any through-thickness stresses within the material can be predicted accurately. A comparison between the predictions of the present model and those obtained from 11 other failure criteria can be found in Noor and Burton.28

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

ack.p: The authors are grateful to Prof. R Christensen of Stanford University for reading of and providing constructive comments on the paper. The authors are also grateful to the organizers of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise for providing technical support and test results.

sec.title: Conflict of Interest
sec.p: None declared.

sec.title: Stiffness coefficients of an off-axis lamina
sec.p: In equation (1), the stiffness coefficients of an off-axis lamina whose fiber direction makes an angle θ with the x direction can be expressed as (26)C11 '=C11cos4θ+C22sin4θ+2(C12+2C66)sin2θcos2θ (27)C12 '=(C11+C22-4C66)sin2θcos2θ+C12(sin4θ+cos4θ) (28)C13 '=C13cos2θ+C23sin2θ (29){∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z=0∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z=0∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z=0 . (30){∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z=0∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z=0∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z=0 . (31)C23 '=C13sin2θ+C23cos2θ (32){∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z=0∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z=0∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z=0 . (33)C36 '=(C13-C23)sinθcosθ (34)C44 '=C44cos2θ+C55sin2θ (35)C45 '=(C55-C44)sinθcosθ (36)C55 '=C44sin2θ+C55cos2θ (37){∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z=0∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z=0∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z=0 . where Cij (i, j = 1 − 6) are stiffness coefficients of an orthotropic lamina (θ = 0° or 90°) and they can be expressed by the engineering constants as follows (38)C11=(1-ν23ν32)E1Θ (39)C12=(ν21+ν31ν23)E1Θ=(ν12+ν32ν13)E2Θ (40)C13=(ν31+ν21ν32)E1Θ=(ν13+ν12ν23)E3Θ (41)C22=(1-ν13ν31)E2Θ (42)C23=(ν32+ν12ν31)E2Θ=(ν23+ν21ν13)E3Θ (43)C33=(1-ν12ν21)E3Θ (44)C44=G23 (45)C55=G13 (46)C66=G12 (47)Θ=1-ν12ν21-ν23ν32-ν31ν13-2ν21ν32ν13 where E1, E2 and E3 denote the orthotropic moduli of an lamina relative to the x, y and z directions, respectively; G23, G13 and G12 are the orthotropic shear moduli in the y−z, x−z and x−y planes, respectively; vij (i, j = 1, 2 and 3) is the Poisson’s ratio for strain in the j direction when stressed in the i direction.
